model_explanation: A flock of pigeons is chaotic and not linear, so saying that three years of lessons are coming into your head one at a time would imply that they are chaotic and not linear

premise: His snobbishness pissed me off.
hypothesis: His condescending attitude made my blood boil.
model_explanation: Condescending means to treat someone with contempt or snobbery, which is what made the person's blood boil.

premise: My coworker left early on me today and left me with a ton of work.
hypothesis: Overjoyed with how my coworker bailed on me today and left me high and dry with a ton of work
model_explanation: A coworker bailing on someone leaves them with a lot of work and is not something to be overjoyed about.

premise: He seemed quite annoyed after hearing about the full story.
hypothesis: When I met the boss he seemed bitter about the whole story.
model_explanation: The boss was very angry about the whole story and seemed bitter after hearing it.

premise: I guess I can make sure you receieve no assistance.
hypothesis: I guess I can lend a hand.
model_explanation: To lend a hand means to provide assistance, but in this context the speaker is saying they will make sure the other person receives no assistance.

premise: I can't stop shaking from the anger, and also I seem to be pale because of the rage.
hypothesis: Trembling for ire, and stricken pale for rage.
model_explanation: Trembling for ire means to be shaken or trembling with fear, and pale for rage means to be pale from the anger.

premise: My husband is talking to some other woman and I want to choke them both.
hypothesis: My husband is talking to some other woman and I feel like strangling them both
model_explanation: If someone is talking to another woman and they both feel threatened then it is likely that the person feels threatened and like they want to kill them both

premise: He was uninvolved in a laughing fit.
hypothesis: He was interwoven in a laughing fit.
model_explanation: To be interwoven in something means to be involved or involved in it, while to be uninvolved in something means to be uninvolved or not involved in it.

premise: I forgot to zip my pant after using the washroom and I walked into a meeting with top executives from my head office
hypothesis: I made a superb impression when I walked into a meeting with top executives from my head office with my fly open.
model_explanation: It is not a good impression to walk into a meeting with your fly open because it makes you look unprofessional and like you don't care.

premise: I have been unsuccessful at quitting smoking for years now.
hypothesis: I have been trying to quit smoking for years now but I am still struggling
model_explanation: Quitting smoking is a very difficult task and if someone has been trying to do it for years they are likely to struggle

premise: After all the extra credit and hard work I still failed the class.
hypothesis: It feels amazing how all the extra credit and hard work I put in still wasn't enough to pass the class
model_explanation: Putting in extra credit and hard work is supposed to help someone pass a class, so it is not amazing that it still wasn't enough.

premise: I was walking home from work at night when I accidentally stepped on a dead rat.
hypothesis: I accidentally stepped on a dead rat while walking home from work and it made me feel really hungry
model_explanation: Stepping on a dead rat is often considered to be a dirty and disgusting thing to do and so finding one on your shoe would make anyone feel disgusted and not hungry.

premise: The shiny new tins tacked to the streaked cat-faces of the pines, all facing east to get sunburned.
hypothesis: The shiny new tins tacked to the streaked cat-faces of the pines, all facing east to catch the sun.
model_explanation: To catch the sun means to get sunburned, which is what the shiny new tins are doing by facing east.

premise: All of this stirred a dullness for her.
hypothesis: All of this stirred an uncontrollable excitement in her.
model_explanation: To stir an uncontrollable excitement means to cause great excitement or arousal, while to stir dullness means to cause a lack of interest or activity.

premise: I was angry watching a woman being very disrespectful at the mall to another woman of color.
hypothesis: I didn't feel enraged at all when I saw the generous woman being extremely disrespectful to another woman of color at the mall.
model_explanation: The woman being extremely disrespectful to another woman of color at the mall is not something to feel enraged about because it shows a lack of consideration for the person who is being disrespected.

premise: The thought made her uneasy, once again feel like something being intensely scrutinized.
hypothesis: The thought made her uneasy, once again feel like something under the microscope.
model_explanation: To be under the microscope means to be closely examined, and in this context the thought is being closely examined.

premise: He gathered fertilizer over the lawn.
hypothesis: He peppered fertilizer over the lawn.
model_explanation: Peppering means to scatter or scatter something.

premise: I'm hoping to take advantage of this story for the rest of the year, at least.
hypothesis: I'm hoping to make hay with this story for the rest of the year, at least.
model_explanation: To make hay with something means to use it to your advantage, so the speaker is hoping to take advantage of the situation.

premise: His playing is an epitome of Romantic.
hypothesis: His playing secured him as a Romantic.
model_explanation: This is a metaphor meaning that his playing is an epitome of Romantic.

premise: My pet bird is always making a noise.
hypothesis: I swear my pet bird is purposely trying to make as much noise as possible
model_explanation: Pet birds are often known to make a lot of noise, so it is likely that the bird is deliberately trying to make as much noise as possible.

premise: Please save yourself, do not carry them.
hypothesis: Save you , save you carrying them .
model_explanation: The idiom save you, save you carrying them is used to suggest that if you want to avoid something, do not carry it.

premise: Save you, save me carrying them.
hypothesis: Save you , save you carrying them .
model_explanation: The idiom save you, save me carrying them is used when the speaker wants to save the other person from carrying the items.
